ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

KITCHEN TILES IN HDB FLATS


    1. Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong asked the Minister for National Development (a) why the Housing and Development Board allows lessees to change kitchen tiles only after a period of 3 years; and (b) whether the HDB will consider (i) allowing lessees to change kitchen tiles during the initial 3-month renovation period or (ii) building flats without tiles in the kitchen so that lessees can select and install their own tiles.

Column: 1001



     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB provides good quality, heavy duty ceramic tiles in neutral colours in the kitchen of its new flats. Most flat buyers are satisfied with the tiles provided. It is only a minority of the buyers who have requested to change the tiles during the initial 3-month renovation period.

    The HDB cannot allow flat buyers to change the kitchen tiles during the first three years because extensive hacking is required. Such hacking may result in the building contractor disclaiming liability during the defects liability period. If renovation is not properly carried out, it may also result in water leakages to the lower floors.

    Most flat buyers do not want to change the kitchen tiles provided by the HDB. If the tiles are not provided, these flat buyers will have to incur additional expenses when they renovate their flats. At present, the HDB is able to provide tiles at lower cost through bulk purchases. This will not be possible when individual flat buyers install their own tiles. Flat buyers will also be inconvenienced as the renovation will take a longer time. Moreover, there is also the risk of water leakages if the tiles are not properly installed by renovation contractors. It is therefore not desirable for the HDB to build flats without tiles in the kitchen.

CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY
(Employment prospects)


    3. Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the construction slowdown, what are the employment prospects in the construction industry.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, despite the construction slowdown, foreign workers still form 60% of our construction workforce. Many applications are still being received from the contractors to employ foreign workers. Graduates of the Construction Industry Training Centre (CITC) also have no difficulty in finding employment.

    Indeed, there are many jobs for Singaporeans to work in the construction industry. The problem is that many Singaporeans have a poor image of construction work. They view the job as dirty, uncomfortable and dangerous, despite the better pay compared to, say, manufacturing. This image of construction work has to change, as not all construction jobs are uncomfortable. Pipe-fitting, electrical wiring and finishing trades are usually conducted under shelter. Structural works, which are carried out under the sun, are often compensated in terms of higher pay. Worksite safety has also improved, with more stringent safety standards imposed by the Ministry of Labour and the safety orientation courses conducted for construction workers.

    To facilitate more Singaporeans to join the industry, the Construction Industry Development Board (CIDB) has implemented a job placement service to place Singaporeans with leading contractors. For those who need re-training, the CITC has also introduced a two-month intensive full-time programme to impart basic construction skills to the worker. It is my hope that in these lean times, more Singaporeans will come forward to join the industry.

TAXIS AND TAXI DRIVER LICENCES
(Figures)


    4. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Information

Column: 1003

(a) how many new taxis were registered in 1985; (b) how many taxi driver licences were issued in 1985; and (c) whether there are plans to de-register dormant licences.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and Information (Mr Ho Kah Leong) (for the Minister for Communications and Information): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to the Member's question is as follows:

    (a) 90 new taxis were registered in 1985, all by Singapore Commuters Pte Ltd (SCL);

    (b) 3,044 taxi driver licences were issued in 1985; and

    (c) As with other licences, taxi driver licences not renewed are cancelled.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): May I ask a supplementary question, Sir, of the Senior Parliamentary Secretary: whether there is any change in the policy of the Government as regards the transferability of licences for the yellow top taxis.

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: Sir, the policy has not changed.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask whether consideration will be given to the transferability of these licences because I hear complaints from drivers of yellow top taxis about the rigidity of this rule, which is adversely affecting their livelihood and their interests?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: Sir, the policy has not changed. It is fair to everybody.

     Mr Bernard Chen (Clementi): Will the Ministry consider de-registering the dormant licences even though they have been renewed, as otherwise the total figure would be inflated?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: Mr Speaker, Sir, let me explain. A taxi driver licence is just a vocational licence which permits the licensee to perform a certain type of vocation, in this case taxi driving. Unlike licensed hawkers whereby they are allocated hawker stalls, licensed taxi drivers are not given taxis to drive. In the case of a licensed hawker, if he does not do business, then he is depriving someone

Column: 1004

else of chance to do business at that hawker stall. In the case of a dormant taxi licensee, he is not in any way depriving anyone else of a chance to have a taxi driver licence as we do not impose a limit on the application for taxi driver licences. So the dormant licensees do not jeopardize the chances of new applications being approved. In fact, though not in a very substantial way, the dormant licensees do contribute towards the revenue of our State by way of payment of licence fees.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Senior Parliamentary Secretary saying that this policy of non-transferability for the yellow top taxi licences is not causing any hardship or is not unfair to anybody? May I ask whether the Registrar of Vehicles has consulted the owners of these yellow top taxis for their views and whether they are very happy at the moment with this inflexible rule against transfers? Has there been any survey carried out among these taxi owners and drivers?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: Sir, here we have to distinguish between a taxi licence and a taxi driver licence. In the case of taxi driver licences we do not impose a limit. But in the case of a taxi licence we do impose a limit because we do not want our city to be over-supplied with taxis.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Parliamentary Secretary realize that it is not a question of over-supply? This is a question of transferability, an owner transferring his taxi to somebody else, I have brought up cases of a father wishing to transfer the taxi licence to his son. And this has been refused. Have their views been sought at all or not?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: Sir, those who want to apply for a new taxi can approach either the NTUC Comfort or SCL for a new taxi, and their applications will be considered.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Why is the Registry not in favour of issuing licences to individuals? Why should they be driven into the arms of the NTUC and to this Ministry of Defence's company, or to the SBS company? What is so wrong about individuals operating their own taxis?

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr

Column: 1005

Speaker, Sir, if I could just take up the question by the Member for Anson.

    The licence to operate a taxi is not an entitlement for which the driver can then pass on from generation to generation.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Why should they not be?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Because there is nothing that entitles them to that particular taxi. Sir, we have to try to be fair to as many Singaporeans as possible so that those who seek to make a living out of taxi driving will be entitled in due course to a taxi. Having had this driving licence to drive a taxi and having had the licence to operate the taxi, if we were to allow transferability from father to son, from son to grandson, then we would be locking up the entire taxi industry into the hands of a few privileged people. In other countries, Sir, they do practise a system like this and the licence to operate a taxi is sold for up to $200,000 or $300,000. This is not the system that we wish to follow.

ROAD SAFETY SENSE OF HEAVY VEHICLE DRIVERS
(Improvement)


    5. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Information, in view of the recent spate of accidents involving buses of the Singapore Bus Service and other big vehicles, (a) whether the Registry of Vehicles will request the operators of these vehicles to introduce new and additional safety measures to safeguard the safety of commuters and other road users; (b) whether the ROV will conduct courses to improve the road manners and to enhance the sense of social responsibility of these drivers; and (c) whether the ROV, together with the Traffic Police, will introduce stringent and corrective measures, including heavy penalties, to deal with inconsiderate and irresponsible drivers of all vehicles.

    6. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Communications and Information what steps his Ministry proposes to take to ensure the safety of passengers on buses operated without any conductors on board.

Column: 1006



     Mr Ho Kah Leong (for the Minister for Communications and Information): Mr Speaker, Sir, as Question No. 5 and Question No. 6 deal with the same subject, with your permission, may I answer them together.

    Sir, the recent accidents involving SBS buses are currently under investigation by the Traffic Police to determine the causes of the accidents. As soon as the investigations are completed, the ROV and the Traffic Police will do a thorough review of the need for additional safety devices on buses. No effort will be spared to make public transport as safe as is humanly possible.

    To do that effectively, we must ascertain the cause or causes of the accidents and take the necessary action to prevent their occurrence. All possible measures which will enhance safety, especially for passengers on buses, will be looked at and implemented where appropriate.

    ROV conducts training courses which include lessons on passenger safety and defensive driving. Bus companies are also conducting their own courses to ensure that safety is not just taught but practised on an on-going basis by their drivers. They should also monitor the performance of their drivers and take corrective action, when necessary, to discipline inconsiderate and bad drivers. Bus companies should also help educate passengers on safety on the bus.

    Sir, the ROV and Traffic Police work closely to ensure that inconsiderate and irresponsible drivers are caught and penalized. The Traffic Police have a system of suspending the driving licences of those with a bad driving record. Such drivers are also encouraged to attend defensive driving courses to correct their driving habits. The ROV suspends or revokes the vocational licences of those with a particularly bad record.

    Sir, each year, about 250-300 people are killed on our roads. As a people, we should strive for total safety on our roads to reduce this number to a minimum. If an accident should occur, the Traffic Police will spare no effort to investigate its cause and take measures to prevent its future occurrence.

Column: 1007



     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta)( In Mandarin): Sir, I would like the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to answer the following questions.

    (1) whether the relevant authority intends to request the bus companies to deploy more conductors and ticket inspectors along the routes where there are many passengers and during peak hours, to help bus drivers ensure passengers' safety on embarking or alighting of buses;

    (2) whether bus companies, particularly the SBS, have made use of public media, the SBC and the press, to systematically and regularly educate the passengers about safety on the buses, alighting or embarking on the buses;

    (3) whether the ROV has suspended the licences of bus drivers, temporarily or permanently, for causing bus accidents, and what are the figures;

    (4) whether there are any preventive courses to be conducted for bus drivers, and how many are attending at present.

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: (In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, to answer these questions about bus conductors, I think we should realize that whether or not there is a bus conductor on board, accidents can also happen. In the past when there were bus conductors, likewise, accidents also occurred. Here, I would like to tell the Member concerned that OMO bus is not unique to Singapore. It has been practised in many countries in the world, for instance, Hong Kong, Japan, France, Holland, Germany and even the US. In these developed countries where the OMO bus system is in operation, the safety record is good. Here again, I would like to stress that bus safety is not only the driver's responsibility or the conductor's responsibility, but the passengers have also a certain responsibility to bear. Therefore, it is the responsibility common to all concerned.

    However, Sir, if the investigation into the bus accidents concludes that such accidents were due to the absence of the conductors, then my Ministry will definitely convey the good suggestion of the hon. Member for Delta to the bus companies concerned for consideration.

Column: 1008



    As regards whether the public media have helped in carrying out publicity to educate the public on safety aspects, I would say yes, as it is a social duty. The National Safety Council, the Traffic Police and the public media have all conducted regular publicity programmes through films or in their literature publicizing road safety. Even in today's Straits Times, you can see pictures and articles teaching the public about how to use the expressways safely.

    The next question is about the revocation and suspension of licences of bus drivers who have had records of accidents. Here I have records showing that for the period March 1983 to the end of 1985 no bus driver's licence had been cancelled. Temporarily suspended licences numbered 180.

    As regards preventive or defensive driving courses for the same period, 154 drivers have attended this course.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): The Senior Parliamentary Secretary has said that the ROV is doing everything humanly possible to make our roads safe. Can he please tell this House how much money was expended last year to educate the public in respect of road safety?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong( In Mandarin): Sir, educating the public about road safety is not the duty of my Ministry alone. Other Ministries and bus and transport companies and operators also have the responsibility. So I am sorry I cannot give the figures requested.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary three supplementary questions, Mr Speaker, Sir? Did I hear the Senior Parliamentary Secretary say glibly that even with conductors, one would still have accidents resulting to passengers on the buses? Has the Ministry or the Registry any figures on accidents to passengers before conductors were done away with and after conductors were done away with? We must have figures. Does the Senior Parliamentary Secretary realize that we must have figures to support this before he can make any statement on this?

    Secondly, does he not accept that the safety of passengers, particularly school

Column: 1009

children, on buses must be placed fairly with the staff operating the buses, the driver and the conductor? Does he not think that it is unreasonable to place the responsibility on school children?

    Thirdly, will the Ministry propose to have perhaps special buses for school children manned by a conductor during the peak hours when children go to school and when they return from school? That might at least ensure the safety of children travelling on SBS buses.

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: (In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, just now in my reply to questions by the Member for Delta, I said that after the recent accidents have been investigated into and if it is found that the causes were due to the absence of a bus conductor, then my Ministry will not hesitate to request the bus companies concerned to consider employing bus conductors on the buses.

    As regards safety of school children, this is of utmost concern to my Ministry. Does the Member for Anson not know that almost all of our schools have school buses? How ignorant can the Member be!

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, would the Senior Parliamentary Secretary outline to this House - he says I am ignorant - what steps the Registry of Vehicles has taken to ensure the safety of school children travelling on buses? Does he not realize that it is overloading the driver with responsibilities, and that it is sometimes almost impossible to ensure the safety of his passengers if the bus is overcrowded, as it often is, during peak hours?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: (In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps he did not hear me out. I said that at present, for most schools, there are special school buses carrying school children. If there are more than 30 students on the bus, then there will be at least one attendant. I want to stress here that the safety of the school children is the question uppermost in our minds. We pay very great attention to this matter. I hope the Member for Anson would not try to make use of the opportunity to scoop up some political capital out of this issue. Before he asks any question, I would like him to get the facts correct first.

Column: 1010

PERMANENT RESIDENCE FOR FOREIGN SPOUSES
(Policy)


    7. Mr Bernard Chen asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what is the present policy on the grant of permanent residence to foreign spouses of Singapore citizens in view of the increasing incidence of such marriages; and (b) pending the grant of permanent residence, whether the applicants can be given social visit passes of longer duration.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, our policy on the grant of permanent residence to non-citizen spouses of Singapore citizens has been explained before in this House. Ideally, we should allow all foreigners married to our citizens to come in for permanent stay. Unfortunately, we cannot afford to be so liberal as Singapore is a small country with no natural resources. Also, our population density of 4,122 persons per sq km is one of the highest in the world. Our foremost duty as a Government is to safeguard and promote the interest of the vast majority of Singaporeans. We will not be fulfilling our responsibility if all foreign spouses are freely allowed in without considering whether or not they will impose an additional strain on our public housing, medical and other social services.

    In 1985, 11,380 foreigners applied for permanent residence, most of whom were relatives of Singapore citizens. In addition, 198,430 foreigners applied for extension of Social Visit Passes. All these people who seek to extend or prolong their stay here

Column: 1011

are potential applicants for permanent residence.

    Permanent residence is a privilege, and not a right which a foreigner can acquire through marriage with a Singapore citizen. If the foreign husband of a Singapore citizen has recognized skills and he is able to contribute to our economic development, we would certainly welcome him to settle in Singapore. If he does not qualify for permanent residence, he can only stay in Singapore provided he holds a valid Employment Pass or Work Permit.

    Our policy on the grant of permanent residence to foreign wives of Singapore citizens is less stringent. However, each case is considered on its own merits. Our citizens cannot expect the Government to grant their wives permanent residence, unless they can show evidence that they are well able to support a family in Singapore, and that their dependants will not later become a burden to the State.

    Applications for long-term Social Visit Pass must also be considered on a case-by-case basis. If those who are not eligible for permanent residence can stay here on a long-term Social Visit Pass, then they will become de facto permanent residents and the pool of such people will grow larger and larger, as evidenced by the nearly 200,000 persons who applied for extension of Social Visit Passes or other Passes last year. Granting long-term Social Visit Passes will therefore not solve our problem of discouraging our citizens who can ill-afford to marry foreigners from doing so. Therefore, a long-term Social Visit Pass can only be given selectively if there are compelling reasons.

    I would like to add that it would be in the interest of those intending to marry foreigners to seek the advice of the Immigration Department regarding permanent stay for their intended spouses beforehand.

    I should also like to point out that the Registry of Marriages as well as the Commissioner for Employment (in work permit cases) have made it clear in writing that marriage does not mean rights of permanent residence.

Column: 1012



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister by way of supplementary questions. First of all, does his Government recognize the sanctity of marriage? May we have an unequivocal answer to that? Secondly, following from it, does his Government recognize the right of a husband and wife to live together? May I say that I am concerned with Singapore male citizens who marry wives from other countries? Would he also tell us the considerations that apply, in this case, before his Ministry allows the wives permanent residence? Is one of the considerations a big bank balance? Or are there other considerations?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, a distinction must be made between sanctity of marriage and a marriage that confers rights of entry, rights of permanent residence or rights of citizenship. In most countries in the world that I know of, marriage does not ipso facto and automatically confer rights of entry and permanent residence. This is also the case with Singapore. Rights of immigration, rights of entry on any pass, rights of permanent residence, are determined in accordance with immigration policy. This is so with most countries in the world. This is so with Singapore too. So the fact that marriage does not automatically confer rights of residence or permanent residence is nothing new. This is the practice in most countries and it does not mean that the sanctity of marriage has been violated.

    As to the question whether there should be a fat bank account, this is absurd, Mr Speaker, Sir. As I have said many times previously in this House, approvals given to foreign spouses cut across all categories. Approval is given on considerations which I have mentioned previously and just now. It is not based only on monetary considerations. It is based on many considerations, including the consideration that the local spouse is able to maintain the intended foreign spouse and that the foreign spouse would not be a liability to the State. It also takes into account other compassionate considerations, such as roots with Singapore, and so on.

Column: 1013



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister tell us - I shall be raising this in the Estimates of his Ministry - how many countries in the world refuse a male citizen from bringing his wife into the country? Could he tell us, instead of saying "most countries"?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Since the Member has said that he would be raising this under the Estimates of my Ministry, let us wait for that occasion, Sir.

EFFECTIVE COUNTER SERVICES COURSES FOR CIVIL SERVANTS


    8. Mr Yeo Toon Chia: To ask the Minister for Finance whether his Ministry will (i) conduct public relations courses for civil servants who work at counters or have to deal with members of the public daily, and (ii) select officers who are good at languages to deal with members of the public in order to create a better image of the civil service.

     Mr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Question 8, Sir.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Civil Service Institute already conducts Effective Counter Services courses for officers who work at counters or have to deal with members of the public. In this financial year, it conducted five such courses for 99 officers from the Ministry of Homes Affairs and the Ministry of Health. Twelve courses are planned for financial year 1986-87. These are specially tailored to meet the needs of the particular Ministry, and more will be conducted at the request of Ministries.

    The CSI also conducted five Telephone Techniques workshops for 121 Division III and IV staff this financial year, to give them the knowledge and skills required for performing their jobs courteously. Five such workshops for clerical and secretarial staff are planned for financial year 1986-87.

    Ministries and Departments also conduct their own training.

    Good public relations and courtesy can also be reflected in the organization of work and the environment at public areas. The Member for Ang Mo Kio may be pleased to know that Work Improvement Teams (WITS) comprising counter and other staff have completed 60 projects that

Column: 1014

have contributed to improving the public's perception of the quality of service they receive. These projects include lessening waiting time at counters, providing better directional signs and more comfortable waiting areas, and reducing the response time of ambulances. In June 1985, the Ministry of Finance organized a special seminar on A Better Public Service, where experiences and ideas on improving counter services were shared.

    As for his second question, the Member for Ang Mo Kio will be pleased to know that we select not only those good at languages but also those with the right dispositions to serve members of the public.

EXPORT CREDIT REINSURANCE SCHEME
(Particulars)


    9. Mr Yeo Toon Chia: To ask the Minister for Finance (a) what are the objectives of the Export Credit Reinsurance Scheme; (b) what are the benefits provided under the scheme; (c) how many companies have benefitted from this scheme; and (d) what was the total amount committed to this scheme as at the latest convenient date.

     Mr Vasoo: Question No 9, Sir.

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Export Credit Reinsurance Scheme was withdrawn in May 1982. Under the defunct scheme, Government would provide reinsurance support to Export Credit Insurance Corporation of Singapore for its underwriting of selected capital goods exported, in order to help exporters compete in the world export market.

    The benefits of the scheme to an exporter were:

    (1) Good security against various commercial and political risks of not receiving payments from overseas buyers;

    (2) The exporter can give more competitive terms to his overseas buyers and venture into new markets with greater confidence, even though such markets may be regarded as more risky than traditional ones.

    Six companies have benefitted from the scheme.

Column: 1015



    As at 31st December 1985, Government's contingent liability under the scheme amounted to $122.4 million.

POTHOLES
(Cause and prevention)

MEDICAL BENEFITS FOR DEPENDANTS
OF FEMALE GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES


    3. Mr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Finance whether he will reconsider the extension of medical benefits to children of female government employees.

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: The Ministry of Finance has always maintained that the guiding principle in providing medical benefits is whether the dependants are truly dependent on the civil servants. Therefore, a female officer is accorded medical benefits in respect of her dependants if she has children solely dependent on her as in the case of a widow, divorcee or a married woman who has been granted a decree of judicial separation. In following this principle, it is assumed that the male officer is the head of the household in our society and has to shoulder the responsibility of providing for the family.

    The issue of whether medical benefits should be extended to the children of female officers who are not widows or divorcees was reviewed by Ministry of Finance in mid-1985. The review noted that the most cogent reason for extending medical benefits to children of female officer is the principle of equal treatment for the sexes which is especially important in our meritocratic system. However, while this principle of equal treatment per se is acceptable, the implications on the private sector companies and the financial implications cannot be overlooked. If the dependants of female officers are provided with medical benefits, there may be pressure on the private sector companies which do not provide such benefits (even to the dependants of male employees) to provide medical benefits to dependants of their employees. Moreover, extension of medical benefits to children of female civil servants would have substantial financial implications and this would not be consistent with other measures taken by the Government to trim public sector cost.

    As the present economic situation weighs against any move which may be interpreted as setting a trend and leading to additional cost, the Ministry is of the view that a decision on the extension of medical benefits to children of female officers should be deferred to a later date.
